_{{64*k}}_
\(\Rightarrow\) Since the total number of workers = _{{20*j}}_
\(\Rightarrow\) Workers who leave the team = _{{10*j}}_
\(\Rightarrow\) Therefore, Workers left for the second time = _{{20*j}}_- _{{10*j}}_ = _{{10*j}}_
\(\Rightarrow\) Since the numbers of workers and number of days to finish the job are inversely proportional we get,
\(\Rightarrow (32 \times _{k}_ ) \times (20 \times _{j}_)\) = Constant
\(\Rightarrow (10 \times _{j}_ ) \times \)(No. of days to complete job second time) = Constant
\(\Rightarrow\) Therefore,\( (32 \times _{k}_) \times (20 \times _{j}_) = (10 \times _{j}_) \times \)(No. of days to complete job second time)
\(\Rightarrow\) Number of days to complete job second time =\( \frac {(32 \times _{k}_) \times (20 \times _{j}_)}{10 \times _{j}_}\)
\(\Rightarrow\) Number of days to complete the job second time = _{{64*k}}_

content.text: You are a contractor and are given a contract to pave a road. It takes you _{{20*j}}_ trained workers and _{{32*k}}_ days to finish the job. Unfortunately there is a problem and you must redo all the work again. _{{10*j}}_ workers leave your team. How much time will it take the remaining to redo the work and complete the job for the second time?
